newsitem.title: FRANCE: French beet test shows partial recovery - analysts.
newsitem.headline: French beet test shows partial recovery - analysts.

text.p: Results of the third sugar beet test by French producers showed thirsty crops partially recovered due to rain in August but final yields would still end up below last year's levels, industry analysts said on Friday.
"Things have improved. But we are heading neither for a great year nor for a disaster," one analyst said.
Analysts predicted the national sugar yield may fall to between 9.0 and 9.6 tonnes per hectare from 9.8 tonnes last year.
French sugar intervention board FIRS has maintained its estimate for a crop of 3.9 million tonnes against 4.2 million last year, assuming a yield of 9.4 tonnes.
Manufacturers' association SNFS said the test carried out on August 26 showed sugar weight per hectare fell by 9.6 percent to 7.647 tonnes from 8.457 tonnes in last year's third test.
This represented a 15 percent fall against the five-year average of 9.016 tonnes.
Analysts have blamed a prolonged dry spell during the growing period but had expected crop prospects to improve due to scattered rains this month.
Good moisture levels helped boost root weight between the second and the third test but hit sugar content, analysts said.
They also said they feared sugar content may fall further if current cool temperatures were to last.
